posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: Good morning everyone! I'm a programmer on a relatively new FRC team that's been around for almost three years. We recently had a meeting with a more experienced team from Brazil and realized that our programming style isn't keeping up with our development and won't meet our future goals. Currently, we're trying to put each component of our robot as a subsystem and each action as a command, activating it in our container. So, I'm asking the Chief Delphi community for help, asking for the opinions of experienced programmers. So, if there's anything I can improve, something wrong with the logic, or even some custom of your team that could help, please write a reply to this post. I appreciate your attention and help.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
Overall it looks great nice job  

Two things that might save you some confusion:  
It would be typical to split `IntakeCommand` into two files called for example `SetIntakeAlgaeSpeedCommand` and `SetIntakePositionCommand`. It can be confusing to others who read your code that a simple `1` or `2` is the difference between what you are setting and also what motor you are changing the behavior of. Generally it’s good if one command does one clear action.  

Try to be more descriptive with variable names. This will be useful if other members of your team need to modify your code or if others need to help you. In `IntakeSubsystem` for example the motors are called `intake` and `algae`. It might be better to call the first `intakeMotor` or even better `intakePivotMotor` or `intakeRollerMotor` or similar (I don’t know what your robot looks like).

A small thing is that it looks like you are creating two instances of your intake and elevator subsystem, one in robot and another in robotContainer. I’m not too familiar with command-based, but I think you keep all your subsystem instances in robotContainer.

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: This is because there are things we did in our old way of programming that we couldn’t express as direct commands—for example, resetting our elevator encoder in teleopInit() or rotating the elevator when placing it in L1. We addressed these limitations by handling them separately.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: This is called the "singleton" pattern and is very common in software engineering. There are many other design patterns that serve different purposes. This is a topic I highly recommend reading up on for anyone interested in computer science or software engineering as a career.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
There is no compelling reason to utilize singletons in FRC; the purpose of a singleton (as opposed to a straightforward global variable) lies in its ability to be overridden in different contexts via the getInstance method, such as within a test suite. Since this feature isn't being utilized effectively, employing singleton patterns becomes unnecessary and adds unnecessary complexity.

I generally dislike global subsystems because they frequently lead to unintended resource contention issues inadvertently.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
My comment was simply to give the pattern a name, not to recommend for or against it.

Learning patterns is useful. Part of learning them is learning when it is or isn't appropriate to use each.
